posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Greetings and welcome aboard!  So glad to see a first-timer take an interest in building effective characters for playing this awesome game.  You've come to the right place, mate!

Now, it will take some time to become familiar with the interworkings but all of us started just like you are... with a blank canvas. First, let's qualify your request a bit further.... a bit longish.

You are actually requesting TWO builds... one for the Original Campaign (OC), i.e. the "Plague Campaign" and another discrete build for the Shadows of Undrentide (SoU) thru Hordes of the Underdark (HotU) expansions.  If you play solo (meaning: complete every quest and all combat opportunities without using hirelings or summons much at all for battles), you can expect to reach level 18 for the OC, level 12-14 for SoU and level 12-14 thru level 28 for HotU.  The OC is considered to be a learning campaign where many of the challenges have been toned down and loot is rather easy to accrue. The SoU thru HotU series is much harder by design.  It will test your build's optimizations better, especially the abridged and stingy SoU modules (there are 3 acts in that campaign).

My advice, as a new player, is to focus on the OC toon first, test out the waters and then decide if your original plan should have some tweaks, or else even go in another direction altogether.  You could just play the same 1-18 levels with the same design for the SoU-HotU adventure, but who knows?  You can always change your mind or at least decide on certain aspects of the build that may need to be altered to broaden the experience or the potential.  Sound like a plan?  Hope so.

What you seem to be inferring is a spellsword, an arcane caster that has sufficient melee prowess to be able to buff and go hand-to-hand against most opponents while still retaining strong offensive casting power.  That means minimal use of polymorph forms like Tenser's Transformation. The most effective combination would probably be the Paladin-Sorcerer CHA synergy, typically employing Divine Might and Divine Shield to bolster their combat effectiveness.  In this case, a human would be best to avoid a -20% combat experience penalty..  An elven Paladin-Wizard would also avoid the penalty, but lose out on the synergy since that combo would need to be an INT-focused build.  In the OC, a CHA build has further non-combat advantages in regards to Persuade checks so consider that in your decision.  Either build will be forced to maintain Lawful Good alignment so you may find yourself a fallen paladin if you stray too far from the RP aspects and lose your lawful ranking (there are many opportunities in the OC to regain accidental evil actions by good ones, but none to counter lawlessness). 

So, just off the top of my head, without outlining any particulars, my instinct is to recommend something like Pal 4/ Src 14 with an ability spread of STR 16 (18), DEX 8, CON 14, WIS 8, INT 12, CHA 16(18) and using feats Power Attack, Still Spell (if wearing full armor or Extend Spell in robes... choose your option), Divine Shield, Divine Might, Weapon Focus (any one-hand), Improved Critical, Blind Fight, Knockdown.  That assures the toon will have Level 7 spells (Level 6 stilled) available for the final battle.  The spread would probably need to be modified slightly to enable Improved Knockdown for a Level 28 build, but let's postpone that idea for the moment.  RDD may come into play in an extended version but never intended to be part of the OC. 

Please read, consider and digest and then decide what your bias is.  If you have never played NWN before, spellcasting can take some practice.  There are many nuances unique to the game, so spellsword may not fit your learning curve well.  You be the judge.  If I have echoed a lot of information about the game you've already become familiar with... well... better safe than sorry, eh?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
DrinkingViking wrote:
and while i can see the advatanges of a multiclass character compared to a pure class, according to what i've been reading its easier to get a college degree than learn the finner aspects of NwN.
So i was interested in a simple build to learn the very basics and then start messing with multiclasses and the like.
Understood.  Apologies for translating your request so poorly the first time. 

Try not to be overwhelmed by the NWN ruleset.  Yes, there are lots of intricacies but take them step-by-step and learn as you go.  The OC has been designed on a gradual learning curve. Check the NWN wiki to help you resolve most of your questions and the ECB will fill in any remaining issues.

It's not that you CAN'T run a single toon through all the campaigns.  It's just not what was intended.  Trying to start SoU with a level 18 toon is pretty much a waste of time because there will be no challenge PLUS you will be dragging all the uber gear, loot and gold over which is so not what SoU was designed for.  As I stated before: it is stingy.  Gold is hard to acquire and gear is far more limiting.  Bioware created SoU to better reflect how the game should be balanced rather than a casual walk through the park requiring little strategy or care.  Trust me.  When you have become comfortable with your success with the OC, that will mark the beginning of what the true NWN experience has to offer.  * 'nuff preaching *

Here is Valerfor's yardstick build, modified slightly to account for the OC level limitations.  Skills have been modified slightly.  Concentration is worthless to any non-caster (a pally is a self-buffer rather than an offensive spellcaster) in an environment where there is no opposed threat of being taunted.  None of the Bioware campaigns have introduced taunting into the creature AI so you can save skill investment from Concentration for custom content where it is a factor.  Also, notice the value I've placed on Extend Spell to lengthen the duration of Divine Favor and Prayer, specifically, while the toon is still in its early stages.  The +12 CHA cap should be relatively easy to reach by combining Eagle's Splendor/Aura of Glory buffs with common nymph cloaks resulting in a final CHA 28 (+9 modifier).  Fully capped, that's a dozen turn attempts per day which should be more than enough in an environment with unlimited resting.

Spoiler [+]

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Greetings Viking and welcome to the ecb guild,

You are doing good to try the original campaigns first and a Paladin is a fine choice for that, being both powerful and interesting as a class. Of the two campaign choices that you have, the second is the best one and involves your character going through SoU to HoTU and finish somewhere between 27-28 lvl. I saw that Hip already provided you with a build for the OC, so i will provide you with another, different one, for the SoU to HoTU campaign. This one is based to the "Puissant Paladin" by Theophilus Fist and myself which can be found in the same thread as the holy knight, later on. The Puissant Paladin has two main differences from the Holy Knight. First, it completely forfeits charisma as a factor in this build, so the option of using Divine Might and Shield isn't there (but read on and i will explain why). Secondly, Puissant Paladin attains the dreaded "Devastating Critical" and he does so, with the maximum Human DC! You will also notice that i don't use a longsword but rather a Greatsword in order to gain both greater damage but also in-game reach.
